BE11:25am

We expect Prime Minister May’s government to survive. Looking further ahead, we maintain our base case that a close variant of the current Brexit deal will ultimately command a majority in the House of Commons. But, in our view, today’s developments skew the risks to that base case further towards a softer, later Brexit — or no Brexit at all.

DRichi ££ up is a big surprise.
Digi Master I don't want a no deal
BE11:25am

So far at least, Parliament has been unable to turn cross-party opposition to a disorderly Brexit into cross-party co-ordination on a single, well-specified alternative. We still expect a slim majority of MPs to ultimately consent to a close variant of the current Withdrawal Agreement. In our view, today’s developments skew the risks to that base case further in the direction of a softer, later Brexit — or no Brexit at all. We think the prospect of a disorderly “no deal” Brexit has faded further. That sharper skew implies a greater probability of an extension to the 29 March Brexit deadline embedded in Article 50.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Morgan Stanley .....

BE11:26am

We expect PM May will seek further concessions from the EU, and
then see a run-off between the government's deal and alternatives, in particular a second referendum. We see a low risk of a no deal outcome (5%), given the opposition of parliament. But we have little conviction on which of the alternative options – referendum, the current deal or early elections – will be chosen. We expect greater clarity by early February, before parliament runs out of time to hold elections before Brexit, assuming that the EU will only agree to a delay once the UK has made a decision on the way forward.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian No deal is for idiots.

Flaneur On Brexit - my black swan is the ERG voting with Corbyn on a 2nd no-confidence motion if it looks like A50 fiddlage is occurring - its the best way for them to ensure any type of Brexit.

BE11:28am

In our previous research, we argued the only way for Prime Minister May to secure a parliamentary majority for her Brexit deal was to secure cross-party backing. This was because at least 20-30 Conservative MPs were committed to voting against any iteration of her current deal - leaving her only option support from Labour Party MPs based on current parliamentary arithmetic.
This pivot appears finally to be materialising. We believe that there remains scope to secure a parliamentary majority for a version of May's current deal, based primarily on a renegotiation of the Political Declaration on the Future Relationship towards a softer form of future relationship, to which the EU27 would be accommodating. We would anticipate, subject to (b), this could take place within weeks.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

b) Second, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has called a no confidence motion in Prime Minister May, to take place tomorrow. Corbyn needs only a simple majority of MPs for a successful confidence vote - the result of which would bring down the government and almost certainly lead to a new general election - which we do not believe is a bullish scenario. Our base case, however, is that the Labour Party loses tomorrow's vote, a view strengthened by declarations this evening that both the DUP (who provide the government with a parliamentary majority) and ERG Conservative rebels will back the Prime Minister.
An unsuccessful confidence vote would open the path to parliamentary
compromise. With the option of a near-term general election being taken off the table, opposition Labour MPs would have a greater incentive to negotiate with the government to secure a Brexit deal that can pass through the House of Commons.

Flaneur @rw42 - which do you think the ERG will go for a 2nd ref or throw their lot in with Corbyn and risk a Lab Gov Brexit?
BE11:29am

c) Finally, indications over the last few days are that the EU27 are willing to extend the Article 50 process to at least July, when MEPs take their seats following the European Parliament Elections. As well as reducing the near-term risk of a no deal Brexit, this allows the UK - and UK MPs - time to formulate a consensus on Brexit, as well as conduct further negotiations with the EU27.
The net result is that from Prime Minister May's Brexit deal being stuck in political deadlock in the UK Parliament, a plausible avenue for compromise is opening.
Moreover, such a compromise will necessarily involve a pivot towards a softer Brexit deal in order to gain support from opposition parties.
The risk to this view are that a) Prime Minister May loses tomorrow's confidence vote or b) she reneges on her pledge in her statement to open up cross-party negotiations or c) the only parliamentary compromise that can be reached is for another referendum on Brexit. We see the third as the greatest risk on the basis of a push from Labour MPs for a second Brexit vote, but still believe the most likely scenario is a compromise based on May's existing agreement, with changes to the Political Declaration on the Future Relationship.
The market should have indication on the direction of travel soon, however.
Following tomorrow's confidence vote, Prime Minister May will seek
parliamentary consensus on a new Brexit plan ahead of Monday, by which time she is obliged to hold another vote on the government's next steps.

BE11:30am

Nomura has also gone long £

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Once the no confidence vote is out of the way, the market will then turn its focus to Plan B next week. In our opinion, the market views Parliament to have a softer Brexit majority and one that is also against a No Deal Brexit.
Theresa May has also indicated that a No deal Brexit is not her intent either. It is why GBP will likely continue to make gains and why we re-enter our short EUR/GBP position at 0.8880.
We do not enter such a position lightly; it was a difficult decision to make as the risk of a loss tomorrow for the government would send GBP lower substantially. But for the time being we believe the market will be looking toward softer Brexit outcomes and GBP will benefit as a result.

UK parliament would agree in advance to implement the policy proposed by the party winning the largest share of the national vote in the EU elections. Not a perfect solution but who has one of those?

Davy to summarise what's said:

red @wayneJthats what a stop is for. diff to go bust if operate with suitable stop and leverage ratio. its boring but it works, even if armed with only slight knowledge.
BE11:39am

The company completed 3,759 homes in FY 2018, which was marginally (c.1%) behind our estimates. Average selling price (ASP) for the full year was broadly flat at £273,000 (Davy: £280,000). Following significant operational improvements Bovis expects to deliver a significant increase in operating margin and full year profit is estimated to be ahead of consensus.
The balance sheet remained strong at the end of 2018, with an expected net cash position of £127m, down from a cash position of £145m. Over the year, the business secured 4,164 new plots for the landbank, a replacement rate of
c.110%. The landbank is in good shape and all of the expected volumes for 2019 already have detailed planning consent. Bovis has also secured 91% of land required for 2020 completions.
Brexit uncertainty is continuing to drive a slowdown in demand for larger homes in particular and, while Bovis has stopped short of providing a view on 2019 trading, it has described initial trading as “encouraging”. The business has good visibility into H1, with an order book of 2,681 units, or circa eight months’ sales.

Lemmy wayneJ: very true, aka "long and wrong", "the yield is still good" etc
Tom Dalgleish " UK parliament would agree in advance"

11:39 am
BE11:39am

BornCynic Mr Authers column was amusing - he stated that he had to stop watching the parliamentary coverage because it was not helping his recuperation.
BE11:39am

Given the group is still benefiting from its strategic initiatives (new house types, strategic land usage and a more controlled production profile), we forecast that margins will grow a further 120bp to 17.5% in 2019, which alongside modest top-line growth is forecast to drive 14% PBT growth. The sales rate through 2018 was 0.5 (0.48x) and the group has ended the year with a broadly flat order book in terms of both volume and value (£521m vs £518m last year). Importantly, Bovis has achieved a customer satisfaction rating of 4* in the year, which is a vast improvement on the 2* rating last year and reflects investment in customer-facing staff/infrastructure, but also a much more controlled year end. Net cash at year end was down from £145m to £127m, which was below our estimate of £153m, reflecting that the sale of Wellingborough into the JV structure is now expected to complete in early 2019 and deliver a £65m net cash benefit. Therefore, we think the current dividend pledge looks well underpinned, which at the current share price implies a yield of 11.3%.

SupposeToBeWorking... RE: Escalation of commitment. I learnt the term "Melian dialogue" today from a more educated friend. It also seems somewhat fitting.
BE11:40am

Bovis states that the housing market remains robust and trading in early 2019 has been “encouraging”. In our view, this is a solid update and the progress the group has made over the last 18 months is impressive. With the margin set to build further and the group seeing the opportunity to sell private units to Housing Associations, we forecast another year of strong growth.

BE11:41am

While total completions grew 3% y/y, broadly in line with our expectation, this was entirely driven by growth in affordable sales. Private completions were flat y/y at 2567. This meant that total ASP was influenced by negative mix and at £273k was 5% below our estimate. On first view we think that revenue missed consensus by c.4% and our estimate by c.6%. To beat on profits, we think the second half operating margin must have been closer to 18% than 17% (JPMe 17%) and at a gross margin level on first view we estimate c.21.8%, around 80-100bps strong than we had been looking for. While this is slightly lighter than our current 2019 estimate of 22%, we would see some scope for upside, that should be sufficient at the very least to offset lower revenue assumptions.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Morgan Stanley incoming:

BE11:47am

Organic revenue growth for the group was -1% in 2018 (vs -2% in 2017 and -8% in 2016) but US Higher Ed Courseware was at the low end of the guided range at -5% organic (MSe -4%) against the original 0 to -5% range and the -3% at 9m. It implies c-11% in Q4. Pearson blames the continuing headwinds in the market and a shift in sales from Q4 to Q1 as the market goes digital.

BE11:47am

Cost savings were well ahead of expectations at £130m in 2018 versus the £85m guided, a beat of £45m. Without this though, Pearson would have missed its £520m-£560m guidance by c£20m, suggesting that revenue has not developed in 2018 as it hoped. The positive is that Pearson has increased the overall size of the cost-saving plan to £330m (from £300m), implying that the company will still get the c£105m of cost savings expected in 2019 and the c£100m in 2020.

alewis2005 interesting bit on elsevier journal editors resigning to start an open-access journal covering the same material: https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2019/01/14/elsevier-journal-editors-resign-start-rival-open-access-journal
11:47 am
BE11:48am

The guidance for 2019 is good enough. Consensus EBITA in that year is £601m, we are on £636m and we had estimated that Pearson might set a range of £610m-£650m of EBITA in 2019. In fact Pearson has set a range [at $1.27] of £590m-£640m. This encompasses our £636m forecast and is ahead of consensus. Pearson expects 2019 adjusted earnings per share of 56.5p to 62.0p (MSe 61.5p). This compares with underlying EPS (ex the one-off tax gain of 19p) of 51p-52p in 2018.

BE11:48am

And Citigroup.

BE11:48am

In the release the group notes that in 2018 the cost efficiency plan came in ahead of plan. The group delivered £130m of savings vs. initial guidance of £80m. Two questions will likely come up: (1) if cost saves were £50m better than forecast, but PSON only delivered operating profit £25m better than the bottom of the range does this signal a miss elsewhere?; (2) are the cost saves sustainable? On the former, the answer appears to be ‘yes’ although importantly this is a function of a less good non-higher ed performance rather than weakness in higher ed; on the latter the answer is ‘partially yes’. The group has confirmed £30m of the savings are incremental.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Focus #2: Guidance for 2019E Set at £590m-£640m — This compares with
current consensus at c. £594m, so it signals consensus upgrades but is not perhaps as emphatic as we thought it might be (we had initially thought there might be a case for the lower bound of guidance being £640m-£650m).

BE11:49am

Given the heavily negative sentiment and the move up into results, we
expect the bears (PSON has 12 Sells vs 1 Buy) to focus on the quality of the earnings and in particular the cost saves point. Although we don’t hold a candle for Pearson (we are Neutral), we think there is danger of a short squeeze as consensus EPS moves up and the investment case further de-risks.

BornCynic Talking of Albert does anyone know what he is saying recently?
BE11:50am

And Liberum's Whittaker -- a very long term seller of Pearson -- wasn't too impressed by the post numbers call.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

[A]s usual, there was a lot of uplifting language on how Pearson would return to growth – at some stage – but light on specific details and there are likely to be a lot more questions about whether Pearson will again need better than guided to cost savings in 2019 to deliver guidance to offset weaker revenues. Firstly, their mantra that the 75% (their figure, not ours) of the business ex-US Higher Ed Courseware is growth is looking more shaky - they admitted on the call that probably only half of that 75% can be categorised as true growth with the rest more in the stabilising category. Secondly, there was no clear explanation as to why 2019 revenue guidance should be flat if US Higher Ed revenues are becoming a smaller part of the group, US K-12 revenues show grow due to the adoption cycle and the rest of the business is improving. Thirdly, they did not give a credible answer as to how they can get back to US Higher Ed Courseware revenue growth after the -5% of this year and the 0% to -5% expected for 2019E. .Fourthly, we are not sure why digital US Higher Ed courseware revenues in 2019 should accelerate back up to mid single digit growth after only 2% in 2018E given trends will not be that much different

BE11:54am

If we are indeed nearing the point where the Fed stops tightening (both QT and Fed Funds), should this offer investors confidence that an equity bear market can be avoided? No! Traditionally the yield curve steepens as the Fed eases immediately prior to a recession. And market confidence that the strong December payroll data means a recession cannot be imminent is equally misplaced…payrolls often accelerate just ahead of a recession.

BE11:58am

Ahead of the year end statement next week (24th) we downgrade to Sell. We continue to think RTN overpaid for Wagamama, an issue compounded by the weak share price reaction to the deal and resultant higher than expected dilution in the rights issue. We cut EPS forecasts a further 6-11% to reflect this and higher than expected interest costs. We estimate that the deal will be dilutive in FY19E and FY20E (-18%/-7%) and only 5% accretive in FY21E after guided synergies of £22m. We don’t think investors should pay more than a post financial crisis trough multiple of 6x EV/EBITDA given ongoing challenges in the core business, integration risks of the deal and likely overhang from the 40% of investors who voted against the deal. This multiple drives our new target of 120p (was 197p).

We think the group’s recent trading has been disappointing given the double digit relative menu price rebasing that has occurred over the last 2 years. We now assume 0% LFL growth for H2 (from +2.5%) leaving FY18E at -1.9% given that UK box office data suggests a weak end to the year for cinema attendance. We expect only +1% LFL growth (was 2%) and a further 50bp contraction in EBIT margins (was -20bp) in the core business in FY19 and expect weak retail footfall and industrywide cost pressures to continue to drag.

BE12:04pm

Here's BMO

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Taking into account working capital movements, the cash generation in 2018 was good and deleveraging continues. Value is being squeezed out of Ghana and 2019 exploration looks interesting but we question whether investors have sufficient confidence in Uganda/Kenya yet. We believe further clarity over those projects is needed to ensure the portfolio has the right balance and can be in a position to stand out from peers.

BE12:04pm

Key Points

Results Impacted by Small Operational Issues. 2018 production (including insurance barrels) averaged 90 kboepd, below our 93 kboepd forecast due to minor operational issues at Jubilee in December. The $200 million disposal proceeds from Uganda have been pushed into 2019, although free cash flow of $410 million was still a little light (BMO $533 million, guidance $500 million) due to an adverse working capital swing. Net Debt was $3.1 billion (2017 $3.5 billion).
2019 Outlook. 2019 oil production guidance is set at 93-101 kbopd (BMO 95 kbopd, CMD loose guidance ~100 kbopd). Capex guidance is unchanged from the CMD and Tullow still expects to pay a dividend of at least $100 million in 2019.
Ghana. Jubilee production was 78 kbopd, missing earlier guidance of 81.2 kbopd due to issues in December that have now been resolved. TEN production of 64.5 kbopd was in line. In 2019, Tullow expects to drill seven new wells and reiterates gross oil guidance of 180,000 bopd.
East Africa. In Uganda, the farm down and FID are expected to complete in H1 2019. In Kenya, Tullow continues to target FID in late 2019 with first oil in 2022.
Exploration. In Guyana, Tullow will drill the Jethro prospect in Q2 as the first of two planned wells on the Orinduik block. The Carapa prospect will be tested on the Kanuku licence in Q3 2019.
View and Valuation. Tullow trades at a 16% discount to our valuation of 238p/sh (sector 25% discount).

BE12:09pm

Mr Kapoor leaves RB with the highest EBIT margin amongst Global HPC peers (2017: 27%), but organic sales growth performance has slowed in recent years, averaging just 1.8% over the period 2016-2018E versus 5.9% 2008-2015. We think it is possible that a new CEO will readdress margin structure. If margins were reset at a lower level, it should enable more investment to revive the top line. It will also likely lead to debates on RB’s portfolio change options

BE12:10pm

Who is the replacement?
This has yet to be announced, but the Board have now initiated a formal process to appoint his successor and will be "considering both internal and external candidates". Given the announcement states that Mr Kapoor intends to retire "by end of 2019”we believe there is the potential for a replacement to be in place before the end of the year. We are surprised that RB has announced the CEO change before a replacement was identified - this might indicate more bad news to come in FY18 reporting on 18th Feb. Finally, we note that Kapoor’s resignation comes just days after Bart Becht’s retirement from JAB

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Fiserv (NASDAQ: FISV) and First Data Corporation (NYSE: FDC) today announced that their boards of directors have unanimously approved a definitive merger agreement under which Fiserv will acquire First Data in an all-stock transaction. The transaction unites two premier companies to create one of the world’s leading payments and financial technology providers, and an enhanced value proposition for its clients.

Under the terms of the agreement, First Data shareholders will receive a fixed exchange ratio of 0.303 Fiserv shares for each share of First Data common stock they own, for an equity value of $22 billion. This represents $22.74 based on closing prices as of January 15, and a premium of 29% to the five-day volume weighted average price as of that date. Following the close of the transaction, Fiserv shareholders will own 57.5% of the combined company, and First Data shareholders will own 42.5%, on a fully diluted basis. The all-stock transaction is intended to be tax-free to First Data shareholders.

wayneJ Why do we not have good satires on like Spitting Image or Not the Nine O'clock news to deal with all this political malarkey?
BE12:12pm

This highly complementary combination will offer leading technology capabilities that enable a range of payments and financial services, including account processing and digital banking solutions; card issuer processing and network services; e-commerce; integrated payments; and the Clover™ cloud-based point-of-sale solution. The combined company will offer comprehensive distribution channels and have deep expertise in partnering with financial institutions, merchants and billers of all sizes, as well as software developers.

“Through this transformative combination, we expect to redefine the manner in which people and institutions move money and information,” said Jeffery Yabuki, President and Chief Executive Officer of Fiserv. “We admire First Data for its excellence in merchant acquiring and global issuing services, and the tremendous progress they have made under Frank’s leadership. We expect this combination to catalyze and support an enhanced value proposition for our collective clients and their customers.”

“I have long admired what Fiserv has achieved over the years, and I look forward to working with the talented associates of both companies as we set a higher standard of innovation and service in the industry,” said First Data Chairman and CEO Frank Bisignano. “Our goal at First Data has always been to provide our clients with the most comprehensive suite of innovative, highly-differentiated solutions and services, and I am excited by the significant value that the combination with Fiserv creates for all stakeholders.”

“We expect the combined company to retain our current investment-grade ratings based on our strong financial profile and excellent free cash flow. Together, this should provide the basis for continued disciplined capital allocation, including debt repayment and share repurchase,” said Yabuki. “We look forward to welcoming First Data’s talented associates to Fiserv as we drive the global digitization of payments and financial technology services.”
